g.text: benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxamide core and three azobenzene arms. Each armcarries the
group. Here, the optimized geometry is shown [

). The azobenzene star studied experimentally by
). The conformation of this star is the same as in the crystalline
-direction to illustrate the stacking of the stars.
) shows the stack made of 20 such molecules. The carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen
atoms are colored dark grey, light grey, red and blue spheres, respectively.
As pointed out in numerous publications devoted to the self-assembly of azo–BTA stars,
stacking between the neighboring star centers along the columns play
an essential role in this system. These two interactions are responsible for assembling a single structure
from very ﬁrst aggregates, that appear at the initial stage of the ordering process. The question of
quantifying these stabilizing forces is open and is, therefore, one of the goals of this study.
Our attention will also be given to the self-assembly mechanism of azo–BTA stars.
According to the latest scientiﬁc ideas in this ﬁeld, three scenarios of the supramolecular
assembly are distinguished: cooperative, isodesmic and ring-chain mechanisms [
